title: Systems of Two Linear Equations
subtitle: Master solving systems using substitution, elimination, and Desmos

sections.title: What is a System of Linear Equations?
sections.content:
A **system of linear equations** is a set of two or more linear equations that share the same variables. On the SAT, you'll typically work with systems of **two equations** with **two variables** (usually $x$ and $y$).

For example:
$$2x + 3y = 12$$
$$x - y = 1$$

The **solution** to a system is the set of values that makes **ALL** equations true at the same time. For two equations with two variables, the solution is an ordered pair $(x, y)$.

sections.title: What Does the Solution Mean Graphically?
sections.content:
Each linear equation represents a **line** on a graph. The solution to the system is the **point where the two lines intersect** - the coordinates that lie on both lines.

When you graph a system, you can literally see where the solution is!

sections.title: One Solution: Lines Intersect
sections.alt: Graph showing two lines intersecting at point (3, 2)
sections.caption: The lines cross at exactly one point (3, 2). This point satisfies BOTH equations.

sections.title: Three Possible Outcomes
sections.content: When you solve a system of two linear equations, there are exactly **three possible outcomes**. The key is understanding how many times the lines intersect:
**1. One Solution** - The lines have **different slopes**, so they cross at exactly one point. This is the most common case on the SAT.

sections.title: No Solution: Parallel Lines
sections.alt: Graph showing two parallel lines that never intersect
sections.caption: These lines have the SAME slope but DIFFERENT y-intercepts. They never cross, so there's no solution.

sections.content: **2. No Solution** - The lines are **parallel** (same slope, different y-intercepts). They never intersect, so no point satisfies both equations.

sections.title: Infinite Solutions: Same Line
sections.alt: Graph showing two lines that are exactly the same
sections.caption: Both equations represent the SAME line! Every point on the line is a solution.

sections.content: In Desmos, when two lines have infinite solutions, they overlap completely. Click the colored circle next to one equation to hide it - you'll see the other line is in the exact same spot!
**3. Infinite Solutions** - Both equations represent the **same line** (one equation is just a multiple of the other). Every point on the line satisfies both equations.

sections.title: The Desmos Strategy
sections.content:
On the digital SAT, you have access to the **Desmos graphing calculator**. This is incredibly powerful for systems of equations!

**Here's how to use it:**

1. Type each equation into Desmos exactly as given
2. Look for the **intersection point** - that's your solution!
3. Click on the intersection point to see the exact coordinates

**Important:** If the problem uses variables other than $x$ and $y$ (like $m$ and $n$, or $a$ and $b$), **replace them with $x$ and $y$** so Desmos can graph them.

sections.title: Variable Substitution
sections.content: If you see a system like $2m + 3n = 12$ and $m - n = 1$, just mentally replace $m$ with $x$ and $n$ with $y$ when typing into Desmos. The intersection point will give you $(m, n)$.
While Desmos is fast for finding solutions, you'll sometimes need algebra - especially when the problem asks you to **set up** a system or when the solution isn't a nice integer.

sections.title: Method 1: Substitution
sections.content:
**Substitution** works best when one equation already has a variable isolated (like $y = 3x + 2$).

**Steps:**
1. Solve one equation for one variable
2. Substitute that expression into the other equation
3. Solve for the remaining variable
4. Substitute back to find the other variable

sections.title: Method 2: Elimination
sections.content:
**Elimination** works by adding or subtracting equations to eliminate one variable.

**Steps:**
1. Multiply equations (if needed) so one variable has opposite coefficients
2. Add the equations to eliminate that variable
3. Solve for the remaining variable
4. Substitute back to find the other variable

sections.title: Elimination Example

steps.description: Notice both equations have 2a. Subtract the second from the first to eliminate a

sections.tip: When coefficients already match, subtraction eliminates the variable immediately - no multiplication needed!

sections.title: Setting Up Systems from Word Problems
sections.content:
Many SAT problems give you a real-world scenario and ask you to set up or solve a system. The key is:

1. **Define your variables** - What do $x$ and $y$ represent?
2. **Find two relationships** - Write an equation for each

Look for phrases like "total," "combined," "sum of," or "costs."

sections.title: Word Problem Example
sections.problem:
A petting zoo sells two types of tickets. The **standard ticket**, for admission only, costs **$5**. The **premium ticket**, which includes admission and food, costs **$12**. One Saturday, the petting zoo sold a total of **250 tickets** and collected **$2,300** from ticket sales.

Which system of equations can find the number of standard tickets ($s$) and premium tickets ($p$)?

steps.description: Define variables: s = standard tickets, p = premium tickets
Second equation: Total revenue (price × quantity for each type)

options.explanation: Coefficients are swapped - $5 goes with standard, $12 with premium
Equations are swapped - ticket count doesn't involve prices

sections.title: No Solution Questions
sections.content:
When a problem says the system has **no solution**, the lines must be parallel.

**What to look for:** Same slope, different y-intercepts.

In slope-intercept form ($y = mx + b$), parallel lines have the same $m$ but different $b$.

sections.title: No Solution Example
sections.problem:
$$y = 6x + 18$$

The system has **no solution**. Which could be the second equation?

steps.description: For no solution, we need the same slope but different y-intercept

options.explanation: This is the same line - would give infinite solutions
Slope is 12, not 6 - lines would intersect
Slope is 12, not 6 - lines would intersect

sections.title: Infinite Solutions Questions
sections.content:
When a problem says the system has **infinitely many solutions**, both equations represent the same line.

**What to look for:** One equation is a **multiple** of the other.

For example, $2x + 4y = 10$ and $x + 2y = 5$ are the same line (the first is just 2× the second).

sections.title: Key Takeaways
items: The **solution** is the intersection point of two lines
**No solution**: Same slope, different intercepts (parallel lines)
**Infinite solutions**: Same line (one equation is a multiple of the other)
**Use Desmos!** Graph both equations and find the intersection
Replace other variables (like $a$, $b$, $m$, $n$) with $x$ and $y$ for Desmos

sections.title: Common Mistakes
sections.content:
• Forgetting to distribute negative signs when subtracting equations
• Mixing up coefficients in word problems (which number goes with which variable?)
• Confusing "no solution" with "infinite solutions" - both involve same slopes!
• Not checking your answer in BOTH equations

sat_tips: Use Desmos whenever possible - it's faster and less error-prone than algebra
For 'set up the system' questions, you don't need to solve - just match the equations
If a question mentions 'no solution', focus on making slopes equal
Always define what your variables represent before writing equations
